data.name: label8.Text
data.value: Yout living toom is full of appliances and controls that consume and access huge amounts of energy. Using smart sensors and smart systems, you can help reduce your carbon footprint without you even realizing.

data.name: label40.Text
data.value:
The Tesla Wall saves energy and money by storing energy during low peak hours when Electricity costs less money, then reuses it.
Its initial purpose was to coincide Solarcity, but now has proved itself way more useful and capable of even generating an income by reselling the electricity.

data.name: label45.Text
data.value:
LEDS are now in season! LEDs use roughly 13-17% of the energy of incandescent light bulbs and roughly 50% of the energy of CFL bulbs for the same amount of lumens. Many homeowners are able to take advantage of the device and potentially cut their electricity bills in half.
Environmental impact LEDs do not contain toxic chemicals, such as mercury. CFLs contain 1-5 mg of mercury per bulb and is very dangerous to the environment; mercury has the potential to alter genetic and vital system in humans and animals. It also changes the pH in water sources which harms fish and other aquatic life. Incandescent bulbs also do not contain the chemicals, but it is highly inefficient in terms of wattage. With less watts required to produce a certain brightness level, LEDs can help reduce the carbon emission levels dramatically. It indirectly produces 50% less carbon than CFL bulbs and 9% less carbon than incandescent bulbs.
Other Benefits LEDs’ performance does not depend on temperature; incandescent and CFL bulbs may or may not work on cold temperatures. As a result, LEDs turn on instantly compared to the others.
Estimated Savings In an average house with 45 light bulbs and 12 cent KWH electricity plan, a homeowner would pay approximately $2,838, $662.26, and $473 for incandescent, CFL, and LED bulbs, respectively, per year. Before, more LEDs would be required to cover the amount of space lighten up by the CFL since it did not spread evenly. Now with omnidirectional LED bulbs, homeowners can buy fewer bulbs for an equal amount of light coverage.
